displays a volcano plot highlighting significant compounds. panel c lists compounds with effect sizes and abundance. panel d outlines kegg pathways with significant differences between groups.\" id=\"f5\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>figure&#xa0;5\u003c/b>. plasma metabolome profile analysis between two groups. \u003cb>(a)\u003c/b> pcoa based on bray-curtis distance of plasma metabolites revealed significant separation between two groups. \u003cb>(b)\u003c/b> volcano plot analysis identified markedly different plasma metabolites, with significantly up-regulated (red) and down-regulated (blue) metabolites highlighted. \u003cb>(c)\u003c/b> heatmap showed the abundance of significantly different plasma metabolites between two groups. \u003cb>(d)\u003c/b> kegg pathways significantly associated with different plasma metabolites.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cp class=\"mb15 w100pc float_left mt15\">differential abundance analysis identified 258 significantly altered metabolites (p &lt; 0.05, |es| &gt; 0.4), including 161 metabolites enriched in ndds patients and 97 metabolites enriched in hcs (\u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure&#xa0;5b\u003c/a>). mapping these metabolites to the kegg database annotated 139 metabolites with kegg ids, of which 41 were associated with specific metabolic pathways. among these, 25 ndds-enriched metabolites&#x2014;including organic acids, heterocyclic compounds, cholesterol, and acetic acid&#x2014;were linked to pathways such as arginine/proline metabolism, phenylalanine metabolism, lysine degradation, tryptophan metabolism, tyrosine metabolism, hif-1 signaling, serotonergic synapse, and tca cycle. conversely, 16 hc-enriched metabolites&#x2014;such as sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine, 2-aminoethanesulfonic acid, methylmalonic acid, and l-cysteine/l-glutamic acid&#x2014;were primarily involved in abc transporters, neuroactive ligand-receptor interaction, glutamatergic synapse, taurine/hypotaurine metabolism, and purine/pyrimidine metabolism (\u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure&#xa0;5c\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">these findings highlight widespread metabolic dysregulation in ndds, with perturbations in amino acid metabolism, energy production (tca cycle), neurotransmitter biosynthesis (serotonergic/glutamatergic pathways), and lipid/cholesterol homeostasis. the enrichment of butanoate and bile secretion pathways in ndds patients may further link gut microbial metabolism to neurodevelopmental dysfunction, while hc-enriched pathways suggest roles for synaptic signaling and nutrient transport in neurocognitive health.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>correlation analysis among gut microbiota, fecal, and plasma metabolites\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">to reveal the effect of gut microbiota and metabolites on host metabolism, spearman&#x2019;s rank correlation analysis was employed to investigate associations between significantly altered gut microbiota, fecal metabolites, and plasma metabolites (\u003ca href=\"#hsm\">supplementary table s1m\u003c/a>). the analysis revealed a positive correlation between hc-enriched microbial species and hc-specific fecal metabolites, with a reciprocal trend observed in ndds patients. notably, \u003ci>anaerofustis stercorihominis\u003c/i>, \u003ci>clostridium leptum\u003c/i>, \u003ci>agathobaculum butyriciproducens\u003c/i>, \u003ci>anaerostipes hadrus\u003c/i>, \u003ci>eubacterium eligens\u003c/i>, and \u003ci>eubacterium hallii\u003c/i>&#x2014;all depleted in ndds&#x2014;exhibited strong positive correlations with fecal butyrate levels (p = 0.0042), which were significantly reduced in ndds patients. conversely, lactate-metabolizing microbes including \u003ci>megasphaera micronuciformis\u003c/i> and \u003ci>m. elsdenii\u003c/i> were enriched in ndds, while lactate-producing species such as \u003ci>clostridium asparagiforme\u003c/i>, \u003ci>ruthenibacterium lactatiformans\u003c/i>, and \u003ci>lactococcus lactis\u003c/i> were depleted. fecal gaba&#x2014;elevated in ndds with no plasma difference&#x2014;correlated positively with \u003ci>b. adolescentis\u003c/i>, an ndds-enriched species (\u003ca href=\"#f6\">figure&#xa0;6\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#hsm\">supplementary figure s4\u003c/a>). fecal dopamine levels&#x2014;significantly reduced in ndds&#x2014;correlated positively with hc-enriched species including \u003ci>clostridium leptum\u003c/i>, \u003ci>akkermansia muciniphila\u003c/i>, and \u003ci>blautia obeum\u003c/i>, but were negatively with ndds-enriched \u003ci>haemophilus\u003c/i> sp. hmsc71h05. epinephrine&#x2014;also reduced in ndds&#x2014;correlated positively with hc-enriched \u003ci>agathobaculum butyriciproducens\u003c/i>, \u003ci>eubacterium eligens\u003c/i>, and \u003ci>streptococcus sanguinis\u003c/i>. fecal acetylcholine showed no group difference, but its derivative phosphocholine&#x2014;positively correlated with \u003ci>roseburia intestinalis\u003c/i> and \u003ci>eubacterium eligens\u003c/i>&#x2014;was reduced in ndds, with a negative correlation to \u003ci>haemophilus\u003c/i> sp. hmsc71h05.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">figure&#xa0;6\u003c/div>\u003cdiv revealed the relationships between the significantly different microbial species and the significantly differential fecal metabolites between the two groups. * p &lt; 0.05; + p &lt; 0.01.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cp class=\"mb15 w100pc float_left mt15\">at the plasma level, ndds-enriched species including \u003ci>b. adolescentis\u003c/i>, \u003ci>lactobacillus sanfranciscensis\u003c/i> were correlated with ndds-specific metabolites such as 4-acetamidobutyric acid and indole-3-acetonitrile (\u003ca href=\"#hsm\">supplementary figure s5\u003c/a>), while hc-enriched species including \u003ci>ruminococcus lactatiformans\u003c/i>, \u003ci>akkermansia muciniphila\u003c/i> were associated with hc-enriched metabolites like l-glutamic acid and phosphoenolpyruvate. similar trends were observed for differentially abundant genera versus fecal/plasma metabolites (\u003ca href=\"#hsm\">supplementary figures s6\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#hsm\">s7\u003c/a>), reinforcing microbiota-metabolism linkages.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">to further explore the comprehensive impact of gut microbiota on intestinal and host metabolism, a venn analysis was conducted. the analysis identified 29 common differentially expressed metabolites from 354 fecal and 591 plasma metabolites (\u003ca href=\"#hsm\">supplementary figure s8\u003c/a>). association studies between these metabolites and significantly altered gut microbes showed positive correlations between ndd-enriched gut microbes and ndd-enriched fecal metabolites, while negative correlations were observed between ndd-enriched microbes and hc-enriched fecal metabolites. the same trends were evident in plasma metabolites (\u003ca href=\"#f7\">figure&#xa0;7\u003c/a>). among the 29 common metabolites, eight were annotated in kegg pathways: 11-dehydrocorticosterone, l-asparagine anhydrous, sarcosine, 1-methylhistidine, lpc(17:0/0:0), trigonelline, adipic acid, and sucralose. specifically:11-dehydrocorticosterone, lpc(17:0/0:0), adipic acid, and sucralose were decreased in feces but increased in plasma of ndd children; 1-methylhistidine and trigonelline were decreased in both matrices; l-asparagine anhydrous was increased in feces but decreased in plasma; sarcosine was increased in both (\u003ca href=\"#f7\">figure&#xa0;7\u003c/a>). these metabolites are primarily involved in steroid hormone biosynthesis, glycine/serine/threonine metabolism, arginine/proline metabolism, choline metabolism in cancer, glycerophospholipid metabolism, and pathways related to amino acid biosynthesis, protein digestion, and mineral absorption. their enrichment in ndd plasma suggests imbalances in energy and nutrient metabolism in pediatric ndds.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>figure&#xa0;7\u003c/b>. spearman&#x2019;s rank correlation analysis between significantly different species and the shared significantly different metabolites in feces and plasma. \u003cb>(a)\u003c/b> association study between the gut species and common metabolites from feces. \u003cb>(b)\u003c/b> association study between the gut species and common metabolites from plasma. the bold metabolites implicate the metabolites with kegg map annotated. *p &lt; 0.05; + p &lt; 0.01.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003ca id=\"h5\" name=\"h5\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>discussion\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">the gut microbiome and its metabolic activities profoundly influence human neurophysiology and mental health. however, the landscape of gut microbial composition, functional pathways, microbial metabolites, and host blood metabolism in children with ndds remains poorly defined. using shotgun metagenomic sequencing and broad-targeted metabolomics, this study systematically characterized differences in gut microbial structure, function, and host-microbial metabolic interactions between ndds children and age-, sex-, and bmi-matched hcs. significant disparities were observed in microbial diversity, taxonomic composition, predicted functional pathways, and fecal/plasma metabolites between groups.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>study cohort and clinical phenotyping\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">forty ndds children and 60 hcs were enrolled, with ndds patients exhibiting significant deficits in social interaction, self-care abilities (e.g., independent eating, hygiene), and developmental milestones. the average developmental age (28.63 &#xb1; 12.96 months) was markedly lower than chronological age (5.18 &#xb1; 1.77 years), with developmental quotient (47.02 &#xb1; 19.29) and iq (42.68 &#xb1; 17.16) reflecting severe neurodevelopmental impairment. clinical phenotypes showed no significant group differences in newborn weight/height, parental age, or delivery mode. notably, children with ndds were predominantly cared for by grandparents, whereas healthy controls were parent-cared, underscoring caregivers&#x2019; critical role during the 0-6-year developmental window. additionally, ndd children commonly had etiological histories of hyperbilirubinemia, premature birth, or prolonged pregnancy, highlighting the importance of prenatal and neonatal care.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>gut microbiome dysregulation in pediatric ndds\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">metagenomic analysis uncovered profound differences in gut microbial composition between ndds patients and healthy controls, characterized by reduced alpha diversity (species richness and evenness) and distinct beta diversity at both genus and species levels. at the phylum level, firmicutes and verrucomicrobia were significantly depleted in ndds, aligning with prior associations of firmicutes reduction with gastrointestinal and neurobehavioral dysfunction. at lower taxonomic levels, ndds patients exhibited decreased abundance of 21 genera (e.g., \u003ci>eubacterium\u003c/i>, \u003ci>akkermansia\u003c/i>, \u003ci>lactococcus\u003c/i>) and 44 species, including key short-chain fatty acid (scfa)-producing taxa such as \u003ci>agathobaculum butyriciproducens \u003c/i>(\u003ca href=\"#b14\">14\u003c/a>), \u003ci>anaerostipes hadrus\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">15\u003c/a>), \u003ci>clostridium asparagiforme\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b16\">16\u003c/a>), \u003ci>eubacterium hallii\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b17\">17\u003c/a>), and other beneficial species including \u003ci>clostridium leptum\u003c/i> and \u003ci>eubacterium eligens. a. butyriciproducens\u003c/i> was reported to improve cognitive impairment in lps-induced and app/ps1 mouse models of alzheimer&#x2019;s disease (\u003ca href=\"#b14\">14\u003c/a>). \u003ci>a. hadrus\u003c/i> is a butyrate-producing bacterium capable of metabolizing 5-fluorouracil (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">15\u003c/a>). \u003ci>c. asparagiforme\u003c/i> produced acetate, lactate, and ethanol as the major products of glucose fermentation (\u003ca href=\"#b16\">16\u003c/a>). \u003ci>e. hallii\u003c/i> is a butyrate and propionate-producing bacterium from infant feces (\u003ca href=\"#b17\">17\u003c/a>). \u003ci>e. eligens\u003c/i> can utilize the galacturonide oligosaccharides dp4 and dp5 derived from sugar beet pectin, strongly promotes the production of the anti-inflammatory cytokine il-10 in \u003ci>in vitro\u003c/i> cell-based assays (\u003ca href=\"#b18\">18\u003c/a>). \u003ci>c. leptum\u003c/i> is exceptional inducers of regulatory t cells (tregs) in the colon and can be considered as therapeutic options for ibd and allergies (\u003ca href=\"#b19\">19\u003c/a>). the decrease of anti-inflammatory and butyrate-producing bacteria in ndds children reminded us a dysbiosis of the gut microbiota. consistently, the depletion of these scfa-producing microbes strongly correlates with reduced fecal butyrate levels in ndds, consistent with the established role of scfas in modulating neuroinflammation and blood-brain barrier integrity in neurological disorders (\u003ca href=\"#b20\">20\u003c/a>). conversely, ndds patients showed enrichment of \u003ci>lactobacillus\u003c/i>, \u003ci>megasphaera\u003c/i>, \u003ci>lactobacillus sanfranciscensis\u003c/i>, and \u003ci>bifidobacterium adolescentis\u003c/i>. megasphaera spp., previously linked to gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain and diarrhea in infants (\u003ca href=\"#b13\">13\u003c/a>), may reflect altered gut dysbiosis in ndds. \u003ci>lactobacillus\u003c/i> species, including \u003ci>l. sanfranciscensis\u003c/i>, a dominant sourdough microbe (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">21\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b22\">22\u003c/a>), have been shown to rescue neurobehavioral deficits in preclinical models of maternal microbiome dysbiosis (\u003ca href=\"#b23\">23\u003c/a>), though their functional relevance in ndds remains unclear. \u003ci>b. adolescentis\u003c/i>, a known gaba producer (\u003ca href=\"#b24\">24\u003c/a>), was significantly increased in ndds. this species modulates host metabolism, catalase activity, and lifespan in preclinical models (\u003ca href=\"#b25\">25\u003c/a>), and heat-inactivated strains promote colonic stem cell activation via paneth-like cells (\u003ca href=\"#b26\">26\u003c/a>). the enrichment of \u003ci>b. adolescentis\u003c/i> and \u003ci>l. sanfranciscensis\u003c/i> in ndds may represent a compensatory host response to microbial dysregulation or dietary influences (e.g., sourdough and buns consumption), though mechanistic validation is needed.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">for predicted functional pathways, all the significantly different pathways were highly abudnant in hc group. further analysis revealed that these microbial pathways were predominantly involved in glycometabolism and amino acid biosynthesis (uniref/ko analysis), reflecting the metabolic dysfunction of the gut microbiota in patients with ndd. these findings highlight metabolic dysfunction, and a dual pattern of depletion (scfa producers) and selective enrichment (gaba producers and opportunistic taxa) in the gut microbiota of children with ndds, underscoring the complex interplay between microbial ecology and neurodevelopmental pathology.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>metabolic perturbations and gut-brain axis links\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">fecal and plasma metabolomics revealed profound metabolic dysregulation in ndds, with reduced fecal butyrate levels directly linked to depletion of butyrate-producing taxa [such as \u003ci>clostridium\u003c/i> spp. and \u003ci>eubacterium\u003c/i> spp.). scfas are critical mediators of gut-brain signaling and neuroinflammation (\u003ca href=\"#b27\">27\u003c/a>). ndds patients exhibited reduced abundance of lactate-producing bacteria (\u003ci>lactococcus lactis\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b28\">28\u003c/a>), \u003ci>ruthenibacterium lactatiformans\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b29\">29\u003c/a>) and \u003ci>clostridium asparagiforme\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b10\">10\u003c/a>)] but increased lactate-consuming \u003ci>megasphaera micronuciformis\u003c/i> (\u003ca href=\"#b30\">30\u003c/a>), despite undetectable fecal/plasma lactate (likely converted to pyruvate or glucose metabolism). this shift may disrupt lactate&#x2019;s role in neural excitation and memory formation (\u003ca href=\"#b31\">31\u003c/a>). elevated fecal gaba in ndds correlated with \u003ci>b. adolescentis\u003c/i> (a gaba producer), but reduced plasma gaba derivatives [e.g., glutamate (\u003ca href=\"#b32\">32\u003c/a>)] suggested impaired central nervous system integration. reduced fecal dopamine and plasma epinephrine in ndds correlated with hc-enriched microbes further implicated microbial dysbiosis in neurotransmitter deficits (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">33\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b34\">34\u003c/a>). stable fecal acetylcholine levels but reduced phosphocholine (a downstream metabolite) indicated altered cholinergic signaling (\u003ca href=\"#b35\">35\u003c/a>). tryptophan metabolism revealed reduced fecal kynurenine metabolites (xanthurenic acid, 3-methylindole) alongside increased plasma kynurenine pathway intermediates, reflecting disrupted gut-liver-brain metabolic crosstalk (\u003ca href=\"#b36\">36\u003c/a>). dysregulated fecal phenolic metabolites (e.g., 3-hydroxy-phenylacetate) and elevated plasma tyrosine derivatives (e.g., thyroxine) highlighted perturbations in phenylalanine/tyrosine metabolism, potentially impacting catecholamine and thyroid hormone biosynthesis.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">kegg pathway annotation indicates significant reprogramming of both microbial and host metabolism in ndds children. specifically, in the gut, ndds children exhibited enhanced amino acid metabolism, accompanied by reduced histidine metabolism and glycerophospholipid metabolism. in contrast, plasma metabolites showed upregulated lipid metabolism, vitamin digestion and absorption, and serotonergic synapse activity, alongside downregulated protein metabolism, glutamatergic synapse function, long-term depression/potentiation, mineral absorption, taurine and hypotaurine metabolism, abc transporters, and the foxo signaling pathway. notably, several pathways displayed opposing trends between gut and plasma: phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan biosynthesis, as well as tryptophan/tyrosine metabolism and steroid hormone biosynthesis, were reduced in the gut but increased in plasma. conversely, purine metabolism, cysteine and methionine metabolism, and glycine, serine, and threonine metabolism were enriched in the gut but diminished in plasma. additionally, three pathways were highly abundant in both gut and plasma of ndds children: the hif-1 signaling pathway (which plays a key role in the body&#x2019;s response to low oxygen concentrations or hypoxia), lysine degradation [via the saccharopine formation and pipecolic acid pathways, clinically linked to severe neurometabolic disorders such as pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy and glutaric aciduria type 1 (\u003ca href=\"#b39\">39\u003c/a>)], and carbohydrate metabolism. collectively, these results suggest that ndds children exhibit dysfunction in nutrient and energy metabolism in both the gut and plasma, with abnormal redox reactions potentially contributing to these metabolic perturbations.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">correlation analysis between significantly differential species and fecal/plasma metabolites revealed several insightful interaction networks that merit consideration in future studies. butyrate, whichxwas significantly decreased in the gut of children with ndds, showed a significant positive association with \u003ci>rothia mucilaginosa\u003c/i>, \u003ci>roseburia intestinalis\u003c/i>, \u003ci>eubacterium eligens\u003c/i>, \u003ci>agathobaculum butyriciproducens\u003c/i>, and \u003ci>eubacterium\u003c/i> sp. cag:180; and also exhibited positive association with known butyrate-producers including \u003ci>anaerostipes hadrus\u003c/i> and \u003ci>eubacterium hallii\u003c/i>. dopamine, another metabolite significantly reduced in ndds children, was significantly positively correlated with ndds-downregulated species including \u003ci>clostridium leptum\u003c/i>, \u003ci>anaerotruncus colihominis\u003c/i>, \u003ci>gordonibacter pamelaeae\u003c/i>, \u003ci>ruthenibacterium lactatiformans\u003c/i>, \u003ci>eisenbergiella tayi\u003c/i>, \u003ci>akkermansia muciniphila.\u003c/i> phosphocholine, which was significantly decreased in ndds children, showed a significant positive association with \u003ci>eubacterium eligens\u003c/i> and \u003ci>roseburia intestinalis\u003c/i>, but a negative association with \u003ci>haemophilus\u003c/i> sp. hmsc71h05. these results suggest that supplementation with butyrate, dopamine, and choline may increase the relative abundance of these beneficial species (which are reduced in ndds children) and thereby alleviate ndds symptoms. conversely, l-lactic acid and gaba, which were significantly elevated in children with ndds, displayed a significant negative correlation with beneficial species enriched in healthy controls (hcs) while showing a positive association with ndds-enriched \u003ci>haemophilus\u003c/i> sp. hmsc71h05. this implies that reducing the abundance of lactate- and gaba-producing species could also mitigate the clinical symptoms of ndds.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">while this study establishes a foundation link between gut microbiome-metabolome interactions and ndds in children, it has certain limitations that warrant attention in future research, including the use of a single-center cohort and the lack of mechanistic validation. in subsequent studies we aim to expand the sample size and enhance geographic diversity to account for regional variations in the microbiota. we will also utilize animal models to dissect causality between specific microbes/metabolites and ndds phenotypes. additionally, the effects of metabolites on the growth of specific microorganisms should be investigated, and microbiota-targeted interventions&#x2014;such as probiotic supplementation and short-chain fatty acid (scfa) administration&#x2014;will be explored for their therapeutic potential in pediatric ndds.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">in conclusion, this study systematically characterized the gut microbiome, microbial and host metabolome profiles in pediatric ndds, underscoring complex microbiota-host metabolic interactions, identifying dysregulated scfa/lactate-producing bacteria, neurotransmitter deficits, and aromatic amino acid metabolism abnormalities, as well as metabolic disturbances of major energy and nutrient metabolism including carbohydrates/proteins/fat digestion and absorption. our findings provide a novel framework for understanding gut-brain axis involvement in pediatric ndds and prioritize microbial-metabolite targets for diagnostic and therapeutic development.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h6\" name=\"h6\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>data availability statement\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">the relevant data have been deposited in the china national genebank database (cngbdb) under the accession number cnp0004326.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h7\"
